entry.title: Radar Chart
Kendall Tau-c(1953)
entry.content:
THE ESTIMATION AND COMPARISON OF STRENGTHS OF ASSOCIATION IN CONTINGENCY TABLES

BY A. STUART

Division of Research Techniques, London School of Economics

1. INTRODUCTION

In testing the significance of an observed association between two characteristics in a contingency table, is generally used. When, however, we wish to measure strength of association, some text-books recommend the use of Karl Pearson's coefficient of contingency, a function of which may be referred to the conventional range (- 1, + 1), although it cannot attain the limits of this range. Kendall (1948a, chapter 13) gives references to the work on the coefficient, largely by Karl Pearson himself, and points out the difficulty of obtaining its sampling variance on the hypothesis of independence.

Yates (1948) proposed a test based on scores for association of characteristics of the kind considered in this paper, but its distribution, as he points out, is only obtained on the hypothesis of independence, and it becomes progressively more inaccurate as the degree of association increases. Williams (1952) has recently considered various tests based on scores.

In this paper, a coefficient is proposed which is independent of scoring systems. It is, in fact, a suitably modified form of Kendall's rank correlation coefficient, which depends only on ordinal properties. It is shown how the existing theory of the coefficient may be used to estimate the population association, to set confidence limits for it, and also to test the difference in the coefficients calculated for two contingency tables.

Since the proposed coefficient depends on rank order, a condition for its applicability is that the rows and columns of the contingency table fall into a natural order. This is, in fact, genierally the case. From one point of view the proposed coefficient may therefore be regarded as availing itself of nmore of the information supplied by the contingency table than does the contingency coefficient, which is invariant under interchanges of rows or columns.

The confidence interval and the significance test obtained by use of the proposed coefficient are conservative, in the sense that a lower boundl is provided for the confidence coefficient, and an upper bound for the probability of wrongly rejecting the hypothesis tested. This is a consequence of the fact that onlv an upper bound is known for the sampling variance of the coefficient, and this is in general a poor upper bound, altlhough sometimes attainable. However, a conservative test is better than no test at all, and this test should be useful in many practical situations, especially where samnple sizes are large.

2. CONTINGENCY TABLES AND RANKINGS

Kendall (1949) has suggested that his rank correlation coefficient t may be calculated for a contingency table whose rows and columns are ordered by the criteria of classification. An table with a grand total of n is regarded as two rankings of n objects according to characteristics for one of which only r separate ranks are distinguished, and for the other only s separate ranks. Looked at in this way, the marginal totals are simply the numbers of objects tied at each level. There is thuis a one-one correspondence between any contingency table and a pair of rankings.

The original context of this suggestion was the estimation of tlle product-moment correlation parameter in the case of non-normal variationl, but there is no reason why the coefficient t should not be used in its own right as a measure of association for contingency tables in which there is a natuiral order for rows and columns.

3. THE DENOMINATOR OF

The test commonly used to test the significance of an observed value of , where there are no ties in the rankings, is described by Kendall (1948b). Like the test for a contingency table, it is made with reference to a hypothetical population obtained by the permutation of sample observations. In calculating the coefficient, we nmay therefore use Daniels's (1944) definition of t in the universe of sample permutations. If , are the ranks allotted to the and objects , and , are scores, one defined on each ranking, given by

this definition is

The summations in (1) extend over all unequal suffixes. The property of the coefficient

is seen from (1) to be a consequence of the Cauchy inequality, the equalities in (2) being attainable only when the members of each set of scores are all + 1 or all - 1. When there are no ties, (1) is equivalent to the more normal definition where S is a function of the number of inversions formed by the two rankings. When we come to consider rankings containing ties, we must further define

and alternative forms are now possible for , for although it remains true that , the denominators of( 1) and (3) no longer agree. If we are inter ested simply in testing whether association exists, the discussion of which form of denorninator to use for t is unnecessary: the test may be carried out directly on the numerator. But if we are concerned to measure association, it is of some importance to choose a denominator so that the limits of the conventional range (-1, + 1) are at least sometimes attainable. With this in mind, we may now examine the possibilities.

  1. If, when there are ties present, we continue to use as the denominator, as in (3), we obtain the coefficient denoted by Kendall (1948b) as .

  2. If, on the other hand, we continue to use (1), the coefficient is denoted by . The fact that some of the , are zero implies that the denominator is decreased in the tied, as compared to the untied, case. Nevertheless, it follows from the Cauchy inequality that the equalities in (2) are not attainable by except in the trivial case when all the scores are zero. It further follows that since has the same numerator but a larger denominator than , and cannot attain + 1, certainly cannot attain + 1. (This is analogous to the similar deficiency of the contingency coefficient.) Where the number of ties is large, the deficiency will be serious. Since we are particularly interested in contingency tables, which often have large marginal totals, we must consider whether a more appropriate form of denominator exists.

  3. Consider the maximum (positive or negative) numerator which can be produced by a sample of n observations arranged in a table. This will be attained when all observations lie in cells in a longest diagonal of the table, and the frequencies in these cells are equal, or as nearly equal as possible. Any move away from this position will decrease the total score . A longest diagonal contains cells, where is the lesser of and

If is a multiple of , the maximum sample score is (If , we are back to the untied case, and (4) reduces to , as it should.) Thus (4) is an attainable upper bound for .

When is not a multiple of , (4) renmains an upper bound, but cannot be attained. This is a quite unimportant deficiency in practice, when is often large and m very small, and the residue of n to modulus m necessarily small. We therefore define

whence It follows that can sometimes attain, and for large n can generally almost attain, 1.

4. THE SAMPLING PROPERTIES OF

Remembering the correspondence between a pair of rankings and a contingency table, let us consider the cell frequencies of an table,

as having been sampled from a population table with frequencies $F_{ik}. Then

and

which, by the ordinary formula for sampling from a finite multinomial population, becomes

where is defined for the population exactly as is for the sample. Thus is unbiased for .
